author: By John Yoon
title: Millions of Indians Living Abroad Have a Say in the Election, Even if They Can’t Vote
description: The number of Indians abroad is small relative to the country’s population. Indian political parties want their support anyway.
content: The dishes at a community center potluck for Indian expatriates near Washington, D.C., ranged from chana masala, a popular northern Indian chickpea curry, to idli, a southern Indian rice cake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Varenikova
title: Ukrainian Drone Strikes Target Russian Nuclear Radar Stations
description: A radar facility more than 1,100 miles into Russia was damaged, satellite imagery showed. The attacks have drawn concern from U.S. officials.
content: In recent days, Ukraine has conducted a series of drone attacks inside Russia, including one of the longest-range strikes of the war, that target radar stations used, at least partly, as early nuclear warning systems by Moscow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Why Are People So Down About the Economy? Theories Abound.
description: Things look strong on paper, but many Americans remain unconvinced. We asked economic officials, the woman who coined “vibecession” and Charlamagne Tha God what they think is happening.
content: The U.S. economy has been an enigma over the past few years. The job market is booming, and consumers are still spending, which is usually a sign of optimism. But if you ask Americans, many will tell you that they feel bad about the economy and are unhappy about President Biden’s economic record.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Chaundler
title: Spain Approves Amnesty for Separatists in 2017 Catalan Independence Vote
description: The measure has divided Spain in recent months, and opponents vowed to keep trying to block it.
content: Spain’s Parliament approved a landmark law on Thursday that grants amnesty to Catalan separatists involved in the illegal October 2017 independence referendum, a reprieve that could apply to hundreds of people, including Carles Puigdemont, the former Catalan leader who has been living in self-imposed exile for seven years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Ukraine Warns of Deepening Russian Threat in the North
description: Analysts say an offensive in the Kharkiv or Sumy regions could stretch Ukrainian troops to the breaking point and allow Moscow to punch through.
content: Top Ukrainian military officials have warned that Russia is building up troops near northeastern Ukraine, raising fears that a new offensive push could be imminent in a region that has become a pressure point on strained Ukrainian forces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: After 100 Years of Pizza, the Future of Totonno’s Is in Question
description: One family has owned the beloved Coney Island pizzeria through fire, flood and a pandemic. Now the business is up for sale.
content: Since it was founded in 1924 by a baker from Naples, Italy, named Antonio Pero, very little has changed at Totonno’s Pizzeria Napolitana. The restaurant has operated in the same one-story building in Coney Island, burned coal in the same brick oven and followed the same recipe to make pizza that is widely held to be among New York City’s finest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: PTSD Has Surged Among College Students
description: The prevalence of post-traumatic stress disorder among college students rose to 7.5 percent in 2022, more than double the rate five years earlier, researchers found.
content: Post-traumatic stress disorder diagnoses among college students more than doubled between 2017 and 2022, climbing most sharply as the coronavirus pandemic shut down campuses and upended young adults’ lives, according to new research published on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: The Right Kind of Tipping Point
description: Global carbon dioxide emissions might have already peaked, according to new estimates, signaling a potentially monumental shift.
content: Amid a deluge of terrifying headlines about destructive tornadoes, blistering heat waves and DVD-sized gorilla hail, here’s a surprising bit of good news: Global carbon dioxide emissions may have peaked last year, according to a new projection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Bird Flu Has Infected a Third U.S. Farmworker
description: The worker had respiratory symptoms, unlike the first two. But the risk to the public remains low, federal health officials said.
content: A third farmworker in the United States has been found to be infected with bird flu, heightening concerns about an outbreak among dairy cattle first identified in March.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Singapore Releases Initial Report on Deadly Turbulence That Hit Flight
description: A man died and more than 70 other people were injured last week when a flight to Singapore from London hit sudden turbulence.
content: The severe turbulence that killed one passenger and injured dozens on a recent Singapore Airlines flight led to sudden changes in altitude and airspeed, Singapore’s Transport Ministry said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 30, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, May 30, 2024.
content: An article on Monday about criticism of plans to turn a waterfront park in Toronto into a spa misstated the location of a garage planned as part of the development. The garage is proposed for the mainland, not on West Island.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: Replacing Prison Uniforms With Custom Suits
description: Bindle & Keep, a suit maker in Brooklyn, offers free formal wear to newly exonerated men and women trying to rebuild their lives.
content: Prison limits self-expression. Inmates are usually forced to identify as a number and, for the most part, can only wear a standard-issue uniform.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Objections to Alito’s Refusal to Recuse
description: Readers discuss the flag controversy involving the justice’s wife. Also: Math for all, not just the few; medical consent; Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and history.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘In a Violent Nature’ Review: Killing Them Softly
description: Chris Nash’s ultraviolent horror movie is an unexpectedly serene, almost dreamlike meditation on a murderous psyche.
content: There is a calm implacability to “In a Violent Nature” that’s deeply unsettling and particularly unpleasant. Yet I was also transfixed: Chris Nash’s direction is so persuasively bold — brazen, really — and bloodcurdlingly coolheaded that his unusual shocker is impossible to dismiss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: Get Your Sauce Library Card
description: Build a sauce library — rich peanut sauce, herby cilantro-mint chutney, lemon-caper dressing — and return to it all week for salads, grain bowls and other easy dinners.
content: Last week, Danielle, a “long-time reader, first-time caller,” reached out with a newsletter prompt too good to refuse: She needs help building a sauce library but is “overwhelmed by all the potential.” (As someone often paralyzed by choice, I get it.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: 6 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: From punk to poetry to politics, we’ve got you covered this week: Our recommended books include Kathleen Hanna’s memoir of life as a groundbreaking figure in music’s riot grrrl movement, Andrea Cohen’s latest collection of sly and engaging poems, and Isaac Arnsdorf’s deeply reported look at the grass roots loyalists who have sustained MAGA as a political force.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Craig Johnson Wants to Give Longmire Fans the ‘Best 3 Minutes’ He Can
description: “Make eye contact, shake their hand, ask them about themselves and then sign their book with a genuine smile,” suggests the author of the Wyoming-set mystery series. The 20th, “First Frost,” is just out.
content: How do you organize your books?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Anderson, Cristal Duhaime, Kaitlin Roberts, Larissa Anderson, Wendy Dorr, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Elisheba Ittoop
title: Episode 4: Ferrets
description: Sam soothes his anxiety by visiting a convention center in Ohio.
content: The best birthday party I’ve ever had was not when I turned 10 or 16 or 21. It was my 44th. Because that was when my friends surprised me by renting ferrets for me to play with in their backyard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: Taking the Fight to Russia: The West Weighs Ukraine’s Use of Its Weapons
description: More NATO allies are backing Kyiv’s pleas to allow its forces to conduct strikes in Russian territory with Western weapons.
content: With Ukraine’s second-largest city bracing for a new Russian offensive, a growing number of NATO allies are backing Kyiv’s pleas to allow its forces to conduct strikes in Russian territory with Western weapons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Paul
title: And Now, a Real-World Lesson for Student Activists
description: A generation raised to believe it could change the world learns that the rest of the world may not share its vision.
content: The encampments have been cleared; campuses have emptied; protester and counterprotester alike have moved on to internships, summer gigs and in some cases, the start of their postgraduate careers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Albert S. Ruddy, Producer Who Won Oscar for ‘The Godfather,’ Dies at 94
description: A creator of the sitcom “Hogan’s Heroes,” he went on to win a second Academy Award for “Million Dollar Baby,” the boxing film starring Hilary Swank and Clint Eastwood.
content: Albert S. Ruddy, who found early success in television as a creator of “Hogan’s Heroes,” the situation comedy about Allied prisoners outwitting their bumbling Nazi captors in a P.O.W. camp, and then became a movie producer who won Oscars for “The Godfather” and “Million Dollar Baby,” died on Saturday in Los Angeles. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: This Is What It Was Like Inside the Courtroom When the Trump Verdict Was Read
description: Late on the second day of deliberations, the judge returned to the courtroom with the announcement of a verdict.
content: It happened very quickly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philippe Lazzarini
title: Israel Must Stop Its Campaign Against UNRWA
description: The commissioner of UNRWA calls for an end to Israeli attacks, both physical and verbal, against its staff and buildings.
content: The war in Gaza has produced a blatant disregard for the mission of the United Nations, including outrageous attacks on the employees, facilities and operations of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: Girls of Color Are Getting Their Periods Earlier. No One Quite Knows Why.
description: Researchers have linked early menstruation to an increased risk of health problems later in life.
content: A new study, published Wednesday, found that girls are starting their menstrual cycles earlier now than in previous decades. The trend is more pronounced for girls from minority groups and those from lower-income backgrounds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Blatt
title: How Some ‘Wheel of Fortune’ Tips Turned Into $50,000 in Prizes
description: The Upshot’s guide helped a New Jersey man, who has some good tips of his own.
content: Last December, the Upshot published a guide to Wheel of Fortune strategies, using data from more than 6,000 bonus-round puzzles. Our guide has influenced the behavior of at least one contestant. Scott Menke, a data analyst from New Jersey, won $52,690 in cash and prizes on an episode last month after creating a strategy based on our article, he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: U.S. Economic Growth in First Quarter Was Milder Than Initial Reading
description: Consumers eased up on spending in the face of rising prices and high interest rates, Commerce Department data shows.
content: Economic growth slowed more sharply early this year than initially estimated, as consumers eased up on spending amid rising prices and high interest rates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Medline Recalls 1.5 Million Adult Bed Rails After 2 Deaths
description: Federal regulators said that the portable bed rails posed a serious entrapment hazard and a risk of death by asphyxiation.
content: Medline Industries, a medical supply company, is recalling about 1.5 million portable adult bed rails in the United States and Canada after two reported deaths involving the product, federal safety regulators said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Trump Can Proceed With Lawsuit Against His Niece, Court Rules
description: The case concerns Mary L. Trump’s disclosure of financial documents to a team of reporters at The New York Times.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump can proceed with a lawsuit against Mary L. Trump, his estranged niece, over her role as a source for a New York Times investigation into Mr. Trump’s finances, a New York State appeals court said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu and Steven Lee Myers
title: Europe Banned Russia’s RT Network. Its Content Is Still Spreading.
description: A study found that hundreds of sites, many without obvious Kremlin links, copied Russian propaganda and spread it to unsuspecting audiences ahead of the E.U. election.
content: The website calling itself Man Stuff News caters to a certain sensibility, with categories like “Backyard Grilling,” “TV Shows for Guys” and “Beard Grooming.” A recent article headlined “Tips for Dads During Labor” offered this nugget of advice: “Just remember to spend some time together before deciding whether or not to give birth.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘Ezra’ Review: This Father Doesn’t Know Best
description: This drama centers on a boy with autism and his divorced dad, with a cast featuring Robert De Niro, Rose Byrne, Whoopi Goldberg and Bobby Cannavale.
content: Success has many fathers, but in the case of Ezra (William A. Fitzgerald), none of them are Max (Bobby Cannavale), his hotheaded divorced dad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Trump Verdict Gets Little Reaction From the White House
description: “We respect the rule of law,” a spokesman for the White House Counsel’s Office said after former President Donald J. Trump’s conviction in the hush-money case.
content: White House officials said little on Thursday after former President Donald J. Trump was convicted of falsifying records to cover up a scandal with a porn actress, becoming America’s first ex-president to be declared a felon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, David McCabe, Will Reid, Rob Szypko, Rachelle Bonja, Brendan Klinkenberg, Michael Benoist, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Alyssa Moxley
title: The Government Takes On Ticketmaster
description: Explaining a case that could reshape the multibillion-dollar live entertainment industry.
content: Over recent years, few companies have provoked more anger among music fans than Ticketmaster. Last week, the Department of Justice announced it was taking the business to court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: What if This Is Our Last Real Election?
description: The stakes for our democracy should be obvious.
content: Some of the Americans protesting the war in Gaza have turned on President Biden. They assert that the government of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is killing huge numbers of civilians, which is true, and that Biden can stop it, which is more doubtful. But how do they deal with the reality that in a second term Donald Trump would be far more pro-Netanyahu and anti-Palestinian than our current president?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: ‘Guilty,’ and History Is Made
description: A single word rings out in a Manhattan courtroom as Donald Trump becomes the first American president convicted of a crime.
content: “Guilty.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Miller
title: How ‘Election Integrity’ Can Change the People Around Trump
description: Some people really believe the fraud claims, and people don’t but make it sound as if they did. Both seem likely to be a part of the Trump future.
content: If you go to Republican National Committee headquarters, one thing you’ll notice, Lara Trump said onstage Friday night, “is that the bulk of the staff — the bodies that are actually in the R.N.C. building — are dedicated to one cause: election integrity.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Schalkx
title: One Designer’s Take on the Perfect Silver Chain
description: Plus: a bright boutique hotel in Laos, dance music at MoMA and more recommendations from T Magazine.
content: Hotels in Luang Prabang, Laos’s temple-dotted former royal capital, have long taken their design cues from the town’s French-colonial past with teakwood floors, louvered windows and creamy stucco walls. Against that backdrop, the new Senglao Boutique Hotel, which opened earlier this month, is a brightly colored standout. Its Laotian owners hired the Bangkok-based designer Saran Yen Panya, who created interiors that channel the nostalgia of the Senglao Movie House, an erstwhile part of the owners’ family business and a fixture in Luang Prabang during the 1980s. “I looked at the quirky and whimsical side of the city’s heritage,” Saran says. For the 31 rooms, some of which open to private terraces, he sourced vintage furniture and commissioned bespoke wallpapers and neon-lit art pieces inspired by traditional textiles and local embroidery. A custom stained-glass window takes center stage in the lobby, as does a work by the British artist David Shrigley, whose tongue-in-cheek work shares similarities with the embroidery commonly found in Laos’s night markets. From $55 a night, senglaoboutiquehotel.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberta Smith
title: The Unknown Ray Johnson Takes the Spotlight
description: The artist you meet in a small, revelatory show is quite different from the one known for mail art and his later gritty samplings of popular culture.
content: In 1949, a young American artist named Ray Johnson left Black Mountain College near Asheville, N.C., moved to New York City and began to explore his prolix talents, both visual and verbal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: ‘The Great Lillian Hall’ Review: A Star Is Fading
description: Jessica Lange is ideally cast as a grande dame of the theater who is facing a reckoning in this well-crafted melodrama by Michael Cristofer.
content: “The Great Lillian Hall” is not afraid to embrace its classicism; had it been made in the 1940s, it would have starred Bette Davis. Like many of the best golden-age melodramas, this HBO film fully commits to both unabashed emotion and a complicated female lead, a role filled by Jessica Lange with a finely tuned mix of showmanship and nuance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Senison
title: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Queens
description: This week’s properties on the Upper East Side, in Chelsea and Kew Gardens.
content: A two-bedroom, three-bath, roughly 1,175-square-foot triplex apartment with a bedroom, a den/home office and a washer/dryer on the first level; an open floor plan with an updated kitchen on the second level; a bedroom and a roof terrace on the third level; plus through-the-wall air-conditioning and built-ins, in a five-story prewar co-op with a super, virtual intercom and shared laundry. Victoria Vinokur, Brown Harris Stevens, 917-952-3452; bhsusa.com
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Edward Wong
title: Under Pressure, Biden Allows Ukraine to Use U.S. Weapons to Strike Inside Russia
description: White House officials said the president’s major policy shift extended only to what they characterized as acts of self-defense so that Ukraine could protect Kharkiv, its second-largest city.
content: President Biden, in a major shift pressed by his advisers and key allies, has authorized Ukraine to conduct limited strikes inside Russia with American-made weapons, opening what could well be a new chapter in the war for Ukraine, U.S. officials said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser and Orlando Mayorquín
title: Idaho Man Is Found Guilty of Murder in ‘Doomsday’ Killings
description: Chad Daybell was convicted of first-degree murder in the deaths of his first wife and two of his current wife’s children. His wife, Lori Vallow Daybell, was previously sentenced to life in prison.
content: A jury in Idaho on Thursday found Chad Daybell guilty of first-degree murder in the killings in 2019 of his first wife and two of his current wife’s children in a case that drew widespread attention because of the couple’s “doomsday” religious beliefs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Thursday Briefing
description: Good morning. We’re covering a push to allow U.S. weapons in strikes within Russia as well as New Delhi’s record heat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘The Dead Don’t Hurt’ Review: A Foursquare Western From Viggo Mortensen
description: Mortensen gives his film a nested, at times unnecessarily complicated structure, but with performances this good, it’s hard to mind much.
content: In making an honest go at reviving the movie western, Viggo Mortensen — who directed, wrote and stars in “The Dead Don’t Hurt,” in addition to composing its score — delivers a few different westerns in one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Draper
title: Departing House Members Ask: ‘Why Am I Here?’
description: A wave of retirees from both parties, including committee chairs and rising stars, say that serving in Congress is no longer worth the frustration.
content: At some point during a routine seven-hour trip from his Oregon district to Washington, Representative Earl Blumenauer, 75, a Democrat who has served in Congress for almost three decades, experienced a depressing epiphany.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Tulsi Gabbard Says She’d ‘Be Honored’ to Be Trump’s Running Mate
description: The former Hawaii congresswoman, who became estranged from the Democratic Party, has drawn intrigue from Donald J. Trump but is considered a long shot.
content: Tulsi Gabbard, a former House member who ran for president in 2020 as a Democrat and then left the party, on Wednesday embraced the idea of joining Donald J. Trump as his running mate on the Republican ticket.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Cincurova and Andrew Higgins
title: Slovak Prime Minister Leaves Hospital 2 Weeks After Assassination Attempt
description: Prime Minister Robert Fico had been shot during a meeting with supporters. The hospital’s director told a TV station Mr. Fico could continue treatment at home.
content: Two weeks after being shot and seriously wounded in an assassination attempt, Prime Minister Robert Fico of Slovakia was released from the hospital on Thursday and taken to his home in Bratislava, the capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Charles Barkley’s Barbs Infuriate and Fuel Players
description: With the future of “Inside the NBA” in flux, athletes say their respect for Barkley means his unsparing evaluations are a rite of passage.
content: When Charles Barkley, the quippy commentator on TNT’s “Inside the NBA” studio show, grew tired of Draymond Green’s aggressive on-court antics several years ago, he made it exceedingly clear that he wanted to punch Green in the face.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Young Woman and the Sea’ Review: Fighting Sexism and Rough Waters
description: Daisy Ridley plays Gertrude Ederle, who persuades her father to pay for swim lessons, and then goes on to be a pioneer.
content: In a brassy set piece from the 1952 classic “Singin’ in the Rain,” its star, Gene Kelly, impersonates a newbie hoofer seeking fame on the Great White Way. “Gotta dance!” he exclaims to anyone he meets. In “Young Woman and the Sea,” Trudy Ederle is fond of singing the 1921 hit “Ain’t We Got Fun.” First loudly, with a ukulele, to convince her early-20th-century immigrant dad to spring for swimming lessons; later, softly, to herself as she prepares to become the first woman to swim across the English Channel. It’s her way of proclaiming “Gotta swim!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Anderson, Kaitlin Roberts, Cristal Duhaime, Larissa Anderson, Wendy Dorr, Marion Lozano and Pat McCusker
title: Episode 3: Manatees
description: Sam makes his underwater dreams a reality.
content: If you ever catch me staring off into space, with maybe a whole ice cream cone melting down my arm, or bath water spilling all over the floor, don’t be alarmed — I’m just imagining myself many miles away, floating in a tropical lagoon, bobbing around with some of my favorite creatures on earth: manatees. This is one of my go-to forms of stress relief. I find it extremely relaxing, a form of meditation. (Manatation?) Because, in my manatee fantasies, I can just float there. There’s nothing to do, nowhere to go, no deadlines, no schedules. I can just be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger
title: Elon Musk’s X to Host Election Town Hall With Donald Trump
description: The social media platform will produce video town halls with Mr. Trump and Robert F. Kennedy Jr., extending its push into politics.
content: X, the social media service owned by Elon Musk, will host live video town halls with former President Donald J. Trump and Robert F. Kennedy Jr. in the run-up to the U.S. presidential election, a major push into politics, according to a person familiar with the plans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: Trump and His Allies Push False Account of What the Judge Told Jurors
description: A tweet from a Fox News anchor falsely said that the jury would not have to settle unanimously on a charge to find the former president guilty.
content: It was a shocking assertion for anyone with even a passing knowledge of American jurisprudence: The judge overseeing the trial of Donald J. Trump had said that jurors could individually choose from a menu of different crimes to find the former president guilty, so long as the total of votes added up to 12.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Patriotism, Diversity and the Election
description: We explore the battle for Senate control.
content: Climate change. Student debt. Diversity, equity and inclusion. The war in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: What the I.C.J. Ruling Actually Means for Israel’s Offensive in Rafah
description: There is a substantial consensus among legal experts that Israel cannot continue its current Rafah offensive without violating the court’s order.
content: I had two thoughts on Friday as I listened to the chief judge of the International Court of Justice tell Israel to halt its military offensive in Rafah, the city in southern Gaza to which more than a million displaced people fled earlier in the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: ‘The Young Wife’ Review: Dancing With Cold Feet
description: A beleaguered bride spirals on her wedding day in Tayarisha Poe’s stylish but overly familiar comedy-drama.
content: In Tayarisha Poe’s “The Young Wife,” a wedding party plays out like a psychedelic fever dream. The camera keens and swoops, birdlike, around the guests — who are decked out in neon eye shadow and bright pastel-colored outfits — and a synth-heavy score lends the whole affair a hint of the uncanny.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whet Moser
title: Friday Briefing: Trump is found guilty on all counts
description: Plus, the U.S. will let Ukraine use American weapons to strike inside Russia
content: Donald Trump has been convicted of all 34 felony counts in a criminal case stemming from a hush-money payment to a porn star on the eve of the 2016 election. He is the first American president to be declared a felon, a stain he will carry as he seeks to regain the presidency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yiwen Lu
title: The Very Slow Restart of G.M.’s Cruise Driverless Car Business
description: An incident that seriously injured a pedestrian in San Francisco led Cruise to take all of its cars off the road. The question now is when they will return.
content: At a sprawling complex in Warren, Mich., General Motors’ hopes for its driverless car future play out in a virtual reality headset offered to visitors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Heinrich
title: Ernie Barnes Paints What It Feels Like to Move
description: The artist, who once played professional football, captured the anatomical and experiential details of bodies in motion in an expansive survey at Ortuzar Projects.
content: The second thing you notice about an Ernie Barnes painting might be its vibrant color scheme. Anchored in earthy reds and browns, it perfectly complements the artist’s virtuosic, almost musical mastery of space and composition. Or it could be the overflowing warmth with which he depicts Black American life that catches your eye. If the painting is “The Sugar Shack,” you might recognize it from an appearance on the 1970s sitcom “Good Times,” where it was shown during the closing credits; from the cover of Marvin Gaye’s 1976 album “I Want You”; or from its dramatic sale for more than $15 million in 2022. You may also have encountered one of the thousands of posters and prints which, throughout his career, he made available at modest prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikita Richardson
title: The Outdoor Dining Season Opener
description: Rooftop beers and pretzels at Greats of Craft, natural wine and pop-ups at Frog, and more reasons to get outside.
content: We are so back. No matter how long I live here, I will never get over the awesome power of late May and early June in New York City. The temperatures are consistently warm, but not too hot. There’s rain, but not too much. And the worst of the pollen has passed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: ‘Ren Faire’ Is ‘Succession’ With Turkey Legs
description: An engrossing documentary debuting Sunday on HBO, it chronicles a Renaissance festival impresario’s effort to find a worthy heir.
content: “Ren Faire,” an engrossing and inventive three-part documentary that debuts on HBO Sunday at 9 p.m., centers on George Coulam, founder of the Texas Renaissance Festival. King George, as everyone calls him, claims he wants to retire; he believes he’ll live for another nine years, and he has a vision for how he wants to spend this remaining time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff
title: Mexicans Are on the Verge of Electing Their First Female President
description: Claudia Sheinbaum is the front-runner in Mexico’s presidential race, but she is wrestling with the image that she could be a pawn of the current president.
content: Claudia Sheinbaum’s list of accolades is long: She has a Ph.D. and a shared Nobel Peace Prize and was the first woman elected to lead Mexico City, her nation’s capital and one of the largest cities in the Western Hemisphere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Experts Question Alito’s Failure to Recuse Himself in Flag Controversy
description: Legal ethicists welcomed the fact that the justice gave reasons for staying on two Jan. 6 cases, a break from court tradition. But they said his rationale was open to criticism.
content: Supreme Court justices seldom give reasons for their decisions to recuse themselves. Even rarer are explanations for deciding to participate in a case when they have been accused of conflicts of interest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Walks in the Park
description: Shh … Royce Ferguson’s puzzle holds secrets.

Or maybe it was Drake himself rapping as “Tupac” and “Snoop Dogg” during the recent Kendrick Lamar beef. The place was hard to get to — from Tokyo, it takes several trains and taxis, and then a long drive into the countryside. But the tragedy of the Japanese wolf had gotten under my skin — this cute little animal (small, by wolf standards) that was once worshiped as a god but was then ruthlessly exterminated in the name of “modernization.” The last known Japanese wolf was killed in 1905. title: The Best Move for the Trump Jury: A Split Decision
description: A trial-watcher’s prediction.
content: With the jury still deliberating, it’s time for those of us who have heard every minute of this trial to place our bets. My prediction is this: Donald Trump will be convicted on nine of 34 counts of falsifying business records. He’ll go down for the nine fraudulent checks he signed in the White House in 2017 — each a piece of a broader effort to falsify business records and, ultimately, to interfere unlawfully in the 2016 election.

title: Episode 6: Bats
description: Sam stares into another hole.
content: The first five episodes of “Animal” featured creatures that are easy to love: Walnut, puffins, manatees, ferrets and the poor extinct Japanese wolf. But the more I thought about this, the more it seemed unfair. We can’t just go around respecting animals because they’re cute. What about all the many millions of beings who are slimy, lumpy, stinky, freaky, ugly, bitey, etc.? Don’t they deserve our attention and respect? Shouldn’t they be seen and encountered?
